At the Sophomore class
meeting on Thursday of last
Week, Pfesident Lockard of
'31 announced the appointment
of managers for the football
and lacrosse squads, which
will meet the yearling class in
the near future. Heinzerling
was created manager of football, while Kyle was made
manager of the sophomore
stick wielders. _The freshmen
have been. practicing on both
of these sports -for the last
three weeks,. while the Sophs
have made little effort to throw
aside their lethargy and defend their laurels.

FRESHMEN ELEVEN
DEFEATED BY PARKERS

CROSS-COUNTRY TEAM
BEATS LEHIGH, 20-35

a.

BLUE JAYS DEFEAT
RANDOLPH-MACON
_
Jays Score Easy Victory Over
Weak Virginians
CAPLAN AGAIN SHINES
Many Substitutions Made; Jays
Roll Up 34 Points
I'laying excellent football against
far inferior opponents, the Johns
Hopkins team defeated the Randolph-Macon eleven in a one-sided
contest, by a score of 34-0. The
Jay team showed glimpses of real
power and the Black and Blue rooters have reason to feel confident
that the remaining three games will
be played in a manner which will
bring credit to their Alma Mater.
From the very first kick-off it was
apparent to the spectators that the
Southerners were no match for their
opponents. After receiving the ball
Jay team did not lose possession
of it until they had, by straight line
plunges, carried the ball over for
the first score of the game. Howard Caplan added the extra point
with his unerring toe. A few minutes later the Jay team scored the
second touchdown of the contest.
This time it was Hu:nie Houston
who traversed the last white marker
to add six more points to the Hopkins score. The try for point was
wide and the score was 13-0.
Southerners' Defense Weak
Randolph-Macon was displaying
a complete lack of defense against
the Jay line plays and it was quite
evident the way the game would end.
Each exchange of punts was netting
the Hopkins club anywhere from
ten to thirty-five yards, and soon
Coach Van Orman began substituting so that at the end of the game
Howard Caplan was the only regular left in the line-up.
The Blue Jay's third score came
five minutes after the beginning of
the second quarter. A well executed
pass, once again from I,yons to
Houston, put the ball on RandolphMacon's 28-yard and Mills, Caplan,
and Besore took the ball over on
three more plays. Caplan added the
extra point, making the score 20-0
in the Jay's favor.
Caplan Plays Entire Game
With most of the starting team
having been withdrawn from the
game Jay rooters expected to see
an immediate let-up in the power
being displayed but in this they were
pleasurably surprised. Lyons was
taken from the game and Ashton
Devereaux took up the job of quarter in a mighty creditable manner.
After an exchange of punts the ball
went to the Jays on the Southerners' 43-yard line! From this point
it took the Hopkins team just five
plays to put the ball across. Once
again Caplan's try for point was
good and the half ended a moment
later with the score 27-0.
The final Hopkins score came in
the middle of the third period on
a pass from Devereaux to Bledsoe.
From this point on the game seesawed back and forth most of the
play being in the Virginian's territory. On several occasions the Randolph-Macon team came very dose
to scoring by the overhead route,
but each time their well-thrown
passes were grounded and they ended the cooptest without scoring.

About two years ago I bought a tin
of Edgeworth tobacco. I was so
pleased with its slow-smoking qualities
and wonderful aroma that I became
an Edgeworth enthusiast and have
smoked no other tobacco since, althouth up to that time I think I can

Moreover, I introduced one of the
other reporters to it. He in turn introduced another and he another until
finally it reached the News Editor.
There are now five of us all smoking
Edgeworth and enjoying it so much
that I thought you might like to have
this little appreciation of what, to
Britishers, is a comparatively unknown tobacco. I wish you every
success.

BLUE JAYS DEFEAT
RANDOLPH-MACON
_
Jays Score Easy Victory Over
Weak Virginians
CAPLAN AGAIN SHINES
Many Substitutions Made; Jays
Roll Up 34 Points
I'laying excellent football against
far inferior opponents, the Johns
Hopkins team defeated the Randolph-Macon eleven in a one-sided
contest, by a score of 34-0. The
Jay team showed glimpses of real
power and the Black and Blue rooters have reason to feel confident
that the remaining three games will
be played in a manner which will
bring credit to their Alma Mater.
From the very first kick-off it was
apparent to the spectators that the
Southerners were no match for their
opponents. After receiving the ball
Jay team did not lose possession
of it until they had, by straight line
plunges, carried the ball over for
the first score of the game. Howard Caplan added the extra point
with his unerring toe. A few minutes later the Jay team scored the
second touchdown of the contest.
This time it was Hu:nie Houston
who traversed the last white marker
to add six more points to the Hopkins score. The try for point was
wide and the score was 13-0.
Southerners' Defense Weak
Randolph-Macon was displaying
a complete lack of defense against
the Jay line plays and it was quite
evident the way the game would end.
Each exchange of punts was netting
the Hopkins club anywhere from
ten to thirty-five yards, and soon
Coach Van Orman began substituting so that at the end of the game
Howard Caplan was the only regular left in the line-up.
The Blue Jay's third score came
five minutes after the beginning of
the second quarter. A well executed
pass, once again from I,yons to
Houston, put the ball on RandolphMacon's 28-yard and Mills, Caplan,
and Besore took the ball over on
three more plays. Caplan added the
extra point, making the score 20-0
in the Jay's favor.
Caplan Plays Entire Game
With most of the starting team
having been withdrawn from the
game Jay rooters expected to see
an immediate let-up in the power
being displayed but in this they were
pleasurably surprised. Lyons was
taken from the game and Ashton
Devereaux took up the job of quarter in a mighty creditable manner.
After an exchange of punts the ball
went to the Jays on the Southerners' 43-yard line! From this point
it took the Hopkins team just five
plays to put the ball across. Once
again Caplan's try for point was
good and the half ended a moment
later with the score 27-0.
The final Hopkins score came in
the middle of the third period on
a pass from Devereaux to Bledsoe.
From this point on the game seesawed back and forth most of the
play being in the Virginian's territory. On several occasions the Randolph-Macon team came very dose
to scoring by the overhead route,
but each time their well-thrown
passes were grounded and they ended the cooptest without scoring.

and wonderful aroma that I became
an Edgeworth enthusiast and have
smoked no other tobacco since, althouth up to that time I think I can

other reporters to it. He in turn introduced another and he another until

There are now five of us all smoking
Edgeworth and enjoying it so much
that I thought you might like to have
this little appreciation of what, to
Britishers, is a comparatively unknown tobacco. I wish you every
success.
Yours faithfully,

Band Goes To New York
For Caine and Concert
In order to play at the Columbia
game the band will leave Baltimore
Friday afternoon for 'New York.
This is the first time that the Hopkins band as such has ever made a
trip. The Athletic Association-is
sending them with the team in order
to interest the New York alumni.
Plans have been made for the band
to play in the lobby of the Commodore Hotel, Friday night.

There will he a meeting
of the entire Student Council in Room 20, Gilman
Hall, at 1 o'clock today.
Every member of the Council is asked to be present.
